title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate by a circle that the lineages that share Node A include: Chinese river dolphin, Amazon river dolphin, La Plata river dolphin, dolphins, narwhal, and porpoises.
The response indicates by a circle that the lineages that share Node A include: Chinese river dolphin, Amazon river dolphin, La Plata river dolphin, dolphins, narwhal, and porpoises.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that sequence analyses of the genes would show that the genes of the La Plata river dolphin have more similarities to those of the Amazon river dolphin than to those of the Chinese river dolphin.

The response indicates that sequence analyses of the genes would show that the genes of the La Plata river dolphin have more similarities to those of the Amazon river dolphin than to those of the Chinese river dolphin.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not indicate that the similarities are likely due to convergent evolution because river dolphins inhabit similar habitats and are subject to the pressures of those environments. Reduced visibility in most large rivers due to silt would lead to a reduction in vision or eye size; long noses are an adaptation for searching for food; streamlined bodies and the dorsal fin are not as critical for stability in rivers as they are in the ocean.

The response indicates that the similarities are likely due to convergent evolution because river dolphins inhabit similar habitats and are subject to the pressures of those environments. Reduced visibility in most large rivers due to silt would lead to a reduction in vision or eye size; long noses are an adaptation for searching for food; streamlined bodies and the dorsal fin are not as critical for stability in rivers as they are in the ocean.
